Title.evidence: Background: Intermittent claudication (IC) is a hallmark symptom of peripheral arterial disease (PAD), causing pain and discomfort during physical activity caused by reduced blood flow to the lower extremities.

Intervention.evidence: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) comparing invasive interventions to Noninvasive treatments were included.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcomes were quality of life (QoL), ankle‐brachial pressure index (ABPI), and maximum walking distance (MWD).

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 11 RCTs with 1379 patients were included in the analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: MWD pooled Mean Difference (MD) = 64.94 [10.77, 115.12] 95% CI, p = .02, 5 studies, and ABPI pooled MD = 0.15 [0.04, 0.26] 95% CI, p = .006, 5 studies.

Harms.evidence: However, invasive interventions were associated with a higher rate of complications, including increased amputation risk.
